input.choice: Composed of bundles of myelinated nerve cell processes
Made up of neuronal cell bodies
Responsible for modulation of the distribution of action potentials
It is the tissue through which messages pass between different areas of gray matter

Correct. This is characteristic of grey matter.

feedback.p: Incorrect.
Incorrect.
Incorrect.
Correct.

body.p: In the resting state of the cell, which ion is found at a concentration of 145 mM in the extracellular fluid?

feedback.p: Correct.
Incorrect. Potassium is found at a concentration of 5 mM outside the cell.
Incorrect. Chlorine is found at a concentration of 108 mM outside the cell.
Incorrect. Oxygen is not found in its ionic state outside of the cell.

body.p: How is the resting membrane potential of a cell maintained?

input.choice: Hormones released from the brain cause a build up of charge outside the cell
The Sodium-Potassium pump actively transports 3 sodium ions out of the cell for every 2 potassium ions brought into the cell
Ions move passivly through the cell membrane to create the voltage difference

feedback.p: Incorrect.
Correct.
Incorrect.The movement of ions through a cell membrane is an active, not passive, process.

body.p: What causes depolarization of a neuron?

input.choice: Sodium gates open, allowing sodium to flood into the cell and make the membrane potential less negative
Sodium gates open, allowing sodium to flood into the cell and make the membrane potential more negative
Potassium gates open, allowing sodium to flood into the cell and make the membrane potential less negative
Potassium gates open, allowing sodium to flood into the cell and make the membrane potential more negative

feedback.p: Correct.
Incorrect. This does not make the membrane potential more negative.
Incorrect. Although the membrane potential does become less negative, this is not the correct cause.
Incorrect. This is neither the correct cause nor the correct definition of depolarizaiton.

body.p: What is the definition of an action potential?

input.choice: The rapid rise and drop in membrane potential that occurs when a neuron fires
The depolarization of the cell membrane
The repolarization of the cell membrane
The hyperpolarization of the cell membrane

feedback.p: Correct.
Incorrect. Although this is part of an action potential, it is not the definition.
Incorrect. Although this is part of an action potential, it is not the definition.
Incorrect. Although this is part of an action potential, it is not the definition.

body.p: What is the definition of a synapse?

input.choice: The rapid rise and drop in membrane potential that occurs when a neuron fires
Specialized junctions through which neurons can signal to each other and other cells via neurotransmitter molecules.
An area of tissue that has been damaged
The amount of time it takes for a neuron to fire another action potential

feedback.p: Incorrect. This is the definition of an action potential.
Correct.
Incorrect. This is the definition of a lesion.
Incorrect. This is the definition of a refractory period

body.p: What is temporal summation of synaptic potentials?

input.choice: When multiple presynaptic neurons stimulate the postsynaptic neuron at the same time
When successive EPSPs at a single synapse occur in rapid succession. The successive potentials occur before the previous ones die out producing an increasing membrane depolarization

feedback.p: Incorrect. This is the definition of spatial summation.
Correct.

Incorrect. This is a class of neurotransmitter.
Correct. Nucleotides form the building block of nucleic acids and do not function as neurotransmitters.

body.p: The ion that enters a presynaptic axon terminal and that directly causes the release of a neurotransmitter substance from the presynaptic terminal is:

feedback.p: Incorrect. This is not the correct ion.
Incorrect. This is not the correct ion.
Correct. Many channels are "voltage-sensitive" to calcium. An influx of this ion results in the opening of the channel gate.
Incorrect. This is not the correct ion.

body.p: Any change in a neuron’s membrane potential that moves the membrane potential to a value more negative than the resting potential (e.g. -120mv) is:

feedback.p: Incorrect. Depolarization occurs when the membrane potential becomes more positive than the resting potential.
Incorrect. An action potential is a nerve impulse that occurs in various types of cells when the cell’s membrane potential rises and falls.
Correct. Hyperpolarization occurs when a cell’s membrane potential becomes more negative.
Incorrect. Hypopolarization occurs when the membrane potential becomes more positive than the resting potential.

Incorrect. This is a function of the autonomic nervous system.
Correct. This is not a function of the autonomic nervous system, as it can be consciously controlled. It is a function of the somatic nervous system.

body.p: The dryness of the mouth (cotton mouth) that occurs when some people are called upon to give an extemporaneous speech is the result of a:

input.choice: sympathetic inhibition of the salivary glands
parasympathetic stimulation of the stress syndrome

feedback.p: Incorrect. Release of acetylcholine is not responsible for this response.
Correct. Inhibition of the salivary glands, which are responsible for producing saliva in the mouth, results in this phenomenon.
Incorrect. This is not what causes this phenomenon.

body.p: Regarding the functions of the autonomic nervous system, an individual at rest, digesting a large meal, would be primarily under the influence of the:

feedback.p: Incorrect. The sympathetic system is involved in the “flight or fight” response.
Incorrect. The somatic system is responsible for the voluntary control of body movements under the skeletal system.
Incorrect. The sensory system is responsible for processing sensory information.
Correct. The parasympathetic system stimulates the “rest and digest” action of the body when it is at rest.
